Issues.Title: refactor(forms): use a type guard to get rid of casts
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [x] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
<!-- Please describe the current behavior that you are modifying, or link to a relevant issue. -->

Not utilizing TypeScript's features which the code would benefit from.

Issue Number: N/A


## What is the new behavior?

When we use a guard, TypeScript infers the type in `if`s correctly. Thus, we can remove this mess of casts and parenthesis:

```
  const validator =
      (isOptionsObj(validatorOrOpts) ? (validatorOrOpts as AbstractControlOptions).validators :
                                       validatorOrOpts) as ValidatorFn |
      ValidatorFn[] | null;
```

and simply write:

```
  const validator = isOptionsObj(validatorOrOpts) ? validatorOrOpts.validators : validatorOrOpts;
```

All this by simply changing the return type of `isOptionsObj` from `boolean` to `validatorOrOpts is AbstractControlOptions`.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information

This has nothing to do with a popular request to strongly type the forms. It's just internal refactoring.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(forms): use a type guard to get rid of casts" (#32541)

Issues.Title: fix(ngcc): consistently use outer declaration for classes
Issues.Body:
In ngcc's reflection hosts for compiled JS bundles, such as ESM2015,
special care needs to be taken for classes as there may be an outer
declaration (referred to as "declaration") and an inner declaration
(referred to as "implementation") for a given class. Therefore, there
will also be two `ts.Symbol`s bound per class, and ngcc needs to switch
between those declarations and symbols depending on where certain
information can be found.

Prior to this commit, the `NgccReflectionHost` interface had methods
`getClassSymbol` and `findClassSymbols` that would return a `ts.Symbol`.
These class symbols would be used to kick off compilation of components
using ngtsc, so it is important for these symbols to correspond with the
publicly visible outer declaration of the class. However, the ESM2015
reflection host used to return the `ts.Symbol` for the inner
declaration, if the class was declared as follows:

```javascript
var MyClass = class MyClass {};
```

For the above code, `Esm2015ReflectionHost.getClassSymbol` would return
the `ts.Symbol` corresponding with the `class MyClass {}` declaration,
whereas it should have corresponded with the `var MyClass` declaration.
As a consequence, no `NgModule` could be resolved for the component, so
no components/directives would be in scope for the component. This
resulted in errors during runtime.

This commit resolves the issue by introducing a `NgccClassSymbol` that
contains references to both the outer and inner `ts.Symbol`, instead of
just a single `ts.Symbol`. This avoids the unclarity of whether a
`ts.Symbol` corresponds with the outer or inner declaration.

More details can be found here: https://hackmd.io/7nkgWOFWQlSRAuIW_8KPPw

Fixes #32078
Closes FW-1507
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ngcc): consistently use outer declaration for classes" (#32539)

Issues.Title: ci: work around `CIRCLE_COMPARE_URL` not being available wih CircleCI Pipelines
Issues.Body:
The commit range that is associated with a CI build is used for a couple of things (mostly related to payload-size tracking):
- Determine whether a size change was caused by application code or dependencies (or both).
- Add the messages of the commits associated with the build (and thus the payload-size change).

NOTE: The commit range is only used on push builds.

Previously, the commit range was computed based on the `CIRCLE_COMPARE_URL` environment variable. With [CircleCI Pipelines][1] enabled, `CIRCLE_COMPARE_URL` is no longer available and the commit range cannot be reliably detected.

This commit switches `CI_COMMIT_RANGE` to only include the last commit. This can be less accurate in some rare cases, but is true in the majority of cases (on push builds). Additionally, it stores the CircleCI build URL in the database along with the payload data, so the relevant info can be retrieved when needed.

[1]: https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/build-processing
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "ci: work around `CIRCLE_COMPARE_URL` not being available wih CircleCI Pipelines" (#32537)

Issues.Title: fix(core): meta addTag() adds incorrect attribute
Issues.Body:

MetaDefinition contains httpEquiv property.

closes #31525

Currently when we use the addTag() or addTags() method with a MetaDefinition containing httpEquiv property a meta tag with an incorrect attribute httpequiv will be added instead of the correct http-equiv attribute.

Issues.Title: Feature Request: Web worker client
Issues.Body:
Hi angular community,

# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
It would likely fit into a separate package such as @angular/web-worker

### Description
Improve the development experience when making use of web workers by providing easier, strongly typed communication between a web worker and an Angular application. Also improving the test-ability of a web worker.

### Describe the solution you'd like
A service that can create clients to communicate with web workers which have decorated observables, properties and/or methods.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
I have built a library to do something similar, although I think it could be made a bit more comprehensive to cover a few more use cases (https://github.com/gleosmith/angular-web-worker).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Feature Request: Web worker client" (#32528)

## üåç Your Environment 5.2.11-200.fc30.x86_64 ng --version ‚Ä¶ Angular CLI: 8.3.1 Node: 10.16.3 OS: linux x64 Angular: ‚Ä¶ @angular-devkit/architect 0.803.1 @angular-devkit/core 8.3.1 @angular-devkit/schematics 8.3.1 @schematics/angular 8.3.1 @schematics/update 0.803.1 rxjs 6.4.0 ### Anything else relevant Researching the cause of the reported missing files found With that hint, I did some version checks. The downloaded package.json shows `"core-js": "2.6.9"` while a new empty local project package-lock.json shows `"core-js": "3.2.1"`. A significant difference. Further checking shows that the StackBlitz project was created with `Angular CLI version (7.0.7)`, while my local environment is `(8.3.1)`. Obviously not directly compatible. After experimenting with ways to get the StackBlitz code updated to the newer environment for awhile, I hit on a simple solution. Before deleting the `/src` folder from the new local project, save a copy of `/src/polyfills.ts`. After moving the downloaded `/src` folder into the project, replace the downloaded `polyfills.ts` file with the saved version. That gets the latest polyfill version, apparently upgrading everything to match the local environment. The `polyfills.ts` file was never touched while creating the start application on StackBlitz. It seems to have the default for the environment used there. So it should be safe to simply replace it. At least it worked for me, with no warnings about version differences.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "polyfill.ts in start application on StackBlitz too old for local build" (#32527)

Given the following route configuration:

```
[

]
```
With this configuration, using the outlet as an entry point to the application, the root module will not load properly and results in the following error:

The `_loadedConfig` property of the route remains `undefined` as the `expandSegmentAgainstRoute() isn't executed.

This issue is only present if the root has a lazy loaded module, works fine with a component or even with a lazy loaded module if the root path is not empty.

Issues.Title: additional files in downloaded StackBlitz zip file can cause confusion
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

The `Building locally` section says (abbreviated) to download the project code from StackBlitz, and use it to replace the `/src` folder of an empty local project.  The downloaded zip file includes files `angular.json`, `package.json` and `tsconfig.json` outside of the source folder.  The deployment information should mention them, and what to do with them.  In this case they are ignored and thrown away, but I suspect that information from them will be needed if extra packages have been installed.  Since the zip file contains more than the `/src` folder, need to be a bit more careful just where it is unzipped.  My first attempt unzipped to the root folder for the local angular project, then `ng new ‚Ä¶` failed because it saw the json files, and refused to create a new project in what it saw as an existing project folder.  Including information about the files, and a brief description of what they are used for would avoid confusion.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

Download the start application from StackBlitz.  Unzip.  See the actual extracted contents, compared to what the deployment page describes.

### What's the affected URL?**

https://angular.io/start/deployment

`Building locally` second paragraph, mixed with creating a new Angular CLI workspace, and replacing the `/src` folder.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "additional files in downloaded StackBlitz zip file can cause confusion" (#32524)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): restore global state after running refreshView
Issues.Body:
Prior to this commit, the `previousOrParentTNode` was set to null after performing all operations within `refreshView` function. It's causing problems in more complex scenarios, for example when change detection is triggered during DI (see test added as a part of this commit). As a result, global state might be corrupted. This commit captures current value of `previousOrParentTNode` and restores it after `refreshView` call.

This PR fixes FW-1548.

Issues.Title: Registering lazy routes (dynamic import) at runtime
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
With the [string loadChildren syntax deprecated](https://angular.io/api/router/DeprecatedLoadChildren) in Angular 8, in favor of the [dynamic import syntax](https://angular.io/api/router/LoadChildrenCallback), it seems it will no longer be possible to register lazy routes at runtime.

Please note that by adding lazy routes at runtime, I'm not referring to loading modules completely unknown to Webpack. These modules would be part of libs that are compiled (AOT) together with the application, so the chunks would be known to webpack, but routes would only be added to the router config as a result of a Web API call.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Basically, I'd like to be able to do the following (from a component or e.g. a ngrx effect), and successfully navigate to the new route and its children:

```javascript
this._router.config.unshift({
  path: 'dynamic',
  loadChildren: () => import(modulePathReceivedFromServer).then(m => m[moduleNameReceivedFromServer])
});
this._router.resetConfig(this._router.config);
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered
The only alternative I can think of is a Webpack plugin doing something similar to what the `AngularCompilerPlugin` does in `contextModuleFactory.afterResolve`.
You can see my detailed analysis, with a simple demo app and the solutions I could think of here: https://github.com/mbinic/dynamic-lazy-routes#dynamic-lazy-routes-experiment.

Constructive criticism from the experts is the best way to learn, so I'd love to get your input even if you think this is a bad idea. And I'd gladly make a PR if this is something you'd support, to angular-cli and webpack :)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Registering lazy routes (dynamic import) at runtime" (#15556)

Issues.Title: creating lazy loaded route --route flag adds route after wild card route
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [x] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... NA ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... with CLI 8.3.0 we can generate the lazy loaded module, and it works great. ng g module testmodule --routing true --route test --module app The only problem is it is standard practice to add wild card routes in app module in, currently the lazy-loaded config is added as the last config. The command should find wild card route and add this lazy loaded route before wild card route ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: Enable extension of #/definitions/project & #/definitions/target
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request
### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
...
- [x] run
...
```

### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Hi folks,
first of all, great Job with the whole CLI & Architect project. A lot of great capabitilies :raised_hands:. 
Some background:
Since three weeks I'm working currently on something to enable the [micro frontends](https://martinfowler.com/articles/micro-frontends.html) approach with angular. 
The first two weeks I spent with evaluating in how this is even possible together with angular:
 _Besides @angular/elements, I have the feeling that web components were never really the focus for the angular team, right?...._
 _**But!!!**..... it works. There are some pitfalls and little details, but all in all, I do have a solution so far, where I'm peacefully happy with to use on a larger environment in enterprise._ 
Some of the things I managed to solve:
- **Share the @angular libraries** between the angular-elements instead of bundling and loading them for each one again.
- **Make use of Ivy for compilation**. This works both for the shared vendor.bundle and for the angular
- **Provide tooling for all of this** (builders, schematics etc.) <-- Spent the third week with

(Yes, I am the one with [2kb angular element](https://twitter.com/simsek_dev/status/1168163228574277639), I'm willing to provide access to the private repo if needed. But I'm not going to make it public right now) 

#### My issue comes with the last point:
On one side, **you provide** great CLI API's for extensions and custom logic, 
but on the other side, **you restrict** people which I don't really get why. 
What I'm talking about is the [json schema for the angular workspace](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular/cli/lib/config/schema.json). 
As long as we tinker with builders, everything is okay. But once you need little more than this, things get complicated:
- [This](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular/cli/lib/config/schema.json#L396) prevents us from extending the project schema definition
- [This](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular/cli/lib/config/schema.json#L398) small WTF
- [This](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular/cli/lib/config/schema.json#L402) prevents us to define a custom targets schema

> ### Why though?

**Let's assume** you have one project composited of mutliple subprojects. 
All of the **sub-projects share** some same information, because 
even though they **can be independent** from each other, 
**they do** have some kind of **relation** 
when it comes to that **bigger composition project**.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> 
Just allow additionalProperties? In which way they disturb? :thinking:
A builder may just use those properties he is interested in and ignore all the others.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> 
So far, that I'm started to code an own angular workspace parser with utilities, because **builder** are allowed to have additionalProperties (WTF!!!). 
And thats the gap I'm using currently to provide some shared information between my angular elements and the container project.

I started to think about using a completely separate custom json for my configuration, which would be sad just because of some flags I'm not getting why they are set.

Kind regards
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Enable extension of #/definitions/project & #/definitions/target" (#15547)

Issues.Title: ci: update saucelabs protractor config to run e2e tests in series rather than parallel
Issues.Body:
Our combined CI usage is often hitting the max number of concurrent sessions on saucelabs.  Currentl the saucelabs job takes 12 sessions at once because the tests run in parallel, instead we should run these in series to only use 1 session.  

It should not have a large impact on overall CI run time as each of the tests take ~10 seconds so we are moving from the Saucelabs steps taking ~1:45 to ~3:00 each.  Based on previous CI runs it looks like this change will still cause the saucelabs test runs to complete ~15 minutes before other jobs in the sequence.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "ci: update saucelabs protractor config to run e2e tests in series rather than parallel" (#15545)

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): minimal=true should not create tests files when using `ng generate` command
Issues.Body:
Before this commit:
`--minimal=true` create project without any testing frameworks and disable e2e, lint, test targets. Thereafter, if in this minimal project we try command `ng generate class|component|directive|guard|module|pipe|service`, it will always create `*_spec.ts` files.

After this commit:
`--minimal=true` override `@schematics/angular` in `angular.json` to not create `*_spec.ts` files when using `ng generate *` commands.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@schematics/angular): minimal=true should not create tests files when using `ng generate` command" (#15541)

Issues.Title: tsconfig update schematics break lazy loaded module compilation for old configs
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [x] update ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes ### Description When I update from 8.3.0.next to 9.0.0-next.3, schematics are run that break the compilation of my lazy loaded modules. I believe this is caused by a CLI generated tsconfig that was `ng new`ed before the tsconfig.app.json split. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ``` git clone git@github.com:StephenFluin/fluin.io.git cd fluin.io git checkout 1b79500152670ea75587feac592400e7be57099d yarn ng update @angular/core@next @angular/cli@next ``` This adds `files` to my `src/tsconfig.json`, which prevents the compilation of my lazy loaded modules. `ng update @angular/material@8  or ng update @angular/material`  it tries to update existing angular packages I just updated to version angular/components#8 to version 9

```

Found 62 dependencies.
```

Issues.Title: External library source maps not included in the vendor chunk
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Description I have a simple Angular application, using an external library `my-lib`. This library comes with one minified `main.js` and `main.js.map`. `main.js` ends with `//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map`. In `angular.json` I have enabled `"sourceMaps": true` and I would expect all vendor source maps to be merged in the final `vendors.js.map`, but it does not seem to be the case. When I open `Developer Tools -> Debugger -> webpack` I see the original minified version of my external library, rather than the individual files inside it. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. Create a simple library with 2 ts files and build it using tsc or webpack with sourcemaps. Run npm pack 2. Create a simple Angular application using the library as a npm package. Enable source maps in `angular.json` 3. Run `ng serve` and check Developer Tools ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 7.3.8
Node: 10.16.0
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 7.2.13

Issues.Title: Error should describe which property has issue in visitPropertyWrite();
Issues.Body:
"Cannot assign to a reference or variable!"
If above error occurs in browser it's  absolutely impossible to trace which ref or variable is causing the issue.

Consider huge application with 100s of developers working if someone messes up it is not possible to trace which variable has caused issue without modifying `compiler_util/expression_converter.ts` OR `compiler.js` to trace.

In below code error should also describe which variable has caused an issue possibly in which file. I wonder how compiler is missing this while building error is coming in browser only.
https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/58be2ff88400d7dc876d357f8cc3eb01b0912aae/packages/compiler/src/compiler_util/expression_converter.ts#L552
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Error should describe which property has issue in visitPropertyWrite();" (#15528)

Issues.Title: feat(button): allow setting default button type globally (#15989)
Issues.Body:
Introduces the `MAT_BUTTON_DEFAULT_OPTIONS` injection token, which allows setting the type of the
button element automatically.
Most browsers set the type attribute to `submit` if omitted, however `button` is usually better
suited as a default value.

Issues.Title: build: mdc cronjob tests should use "develop" branch

MDC seems to do their primary work in the "develop" branch. We
discussed in the team meeting that we want to run tests against
that branch as "master" is just their release staging branch.

The goal of the snapshot job is to detect issues as soon as
possible so that we can notify MDC in case of possible changes
that negatively impact us.

Issues.Title: build: move edge browser test to saucelabs
Issues.Body:
Browserstack Edge is currently very flaky and we don't seem
to be able to fix the flakiness on our end. Recording and debugging
live browserstack instances doesn't seem to help and the behavior
of the browser seems cached. e.g. commit that sets up the MDC
theme for the tests is not reflected in the BrowserStack browser video.

All the test failures are not reproducible locally in Edge, nor do they
reproduce if the tests are executed through BrowserStack from the
local machine (following the CI steps locally).

Since we don't want to spend too much time on it, and Edge runs
extremely slow and flaky on BrowserStack anyway.. we move it
over to Saucelabs.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: move edge browser test to saucelabs" (#16985)

Issues.Title: fix(progress-spinner): animation node inserted into wrong style root when using ngIf with ShadowDom encapsulation
Issues.Body: If the progress spinner is inside the shadow DOM, we attach the `style` tag with the animation to the shadow root, however since we do the insertion inside the constructor, the spinner might not have been moved into the shadow root yet. These changes move the logic into `ngOnInit` which fires late enough for the node to be in the correct place.
